name: NewYorker
text: "I know there is no way to guarantee safety for my baby, who, at 37 weeks, rides in my uterus while I work as a pediatric hospitalist amid the blossoming pandemic in Texas," @HumanitiesMD writes. https://t.co/94MiRJSKMo

name: NewYorker
text:
#FreeBritney supporters seem to be reacting to a broader sense in which mega-celebrities become, in effect, prisoners of their own success and those who stand to gain from it, @frynaomifry writes.

name: NewYorker
text: Children of African immigrants born in Italy may spend their whole lives there considered foreigners by the law. Some are fighting to change that. Listen on this week's episode of #NewYorkerRadio. https://t.co/BOIc0051Rg

name: NewYorker
text: "I believed I could keep my sons alive by loving them," Elizabeth Alexander writes, "believed in the magical powers of complete adoration and a love ethic that would permeate their lives." https://t.co/vn06x59YHx

name: NewYorker
text: “This man’s life will not be in vain,” one protester said, at the site of George Floyd’s murder. “This is going worldwide. The entire world is hearing us.” https://t.co/FUdDInyBAC

name: NewYorker
text: “A lot of the talk about quarantine cooking, in the beginning, was, like, ‘Here’s 20 ways to use a can of tuna,’ ” James O’Donnell said. “A lot of people at home could probably use feeling connected to the natural world right now.” https://t.co/xUu4LFCP0O

name: NewYorker
text: "Frozen food is a shortcut, but so is takeout, and most takeout is not actually built to travel," @hannahgoldfield writes. "Restaurant-quality frozen food is as fast, if not faster, nearly as effortless, and often more delicious." https://t.co/7eN5XGLYPY

name: NewYorker
text: We’ve learned to move past Donald Trump’s use of the Presidency as a protection racket and extortion machine, Masha Gessen writes, and we’ll move past Goya, too. But where will that take us? https://t.co/cUaJpqClDH

name: NewYorker
text: “I think that cinema was always so successful because it replicated this dream state,” Richard Linklater said. “Dark room, totally immersed. The lights would come up, and I forgot who I was for the last two hours.” https://t.co/Jcxg9zEndI

name: NewYorker
text: For half a century, the particulars of Flannery O’Connor’s bigotry have been held close by executors, smoothed over by editors, and justified by exegetes, as if to save O’Connor from herself. https://t.co/RI8jBjOdFc

name: NewYorker
text: “How did school turn Raffi into a person, a member of society, someone who sat still for up to 15 minutes at a time and didn’t seem to just randomly start throwing things at people’s heads? This part of it was a mystery to us,” @keithgessen writes. https://t.co/y2iXYe35fJ

name: NewYorker
text: A tech C.E.O. was asked to start a Web site that would match hospitals and medical suppliers. What followed provides an inside glimpse of the dysfunction emanating from Trump’s Washington in the midst of a pandemic. https://t.co/GRzSzM7yJE

name: NewYorker
text: Who was King David? Was he the all-powerful king described in the Bible? Or was he, as some archeologists believe, a small-time Bedouin sheikh? https://t.co/BoQx38nozN

name: NewYorker
text: No criticism that John Lewis issued about President Trump was as strong an indictment as the simple facts of his life, @jelani9 writes, “born to Alabama sharecroppers, stalwart of SNCC, leader, exemplar of humility.” https://t.co/XpHWRMsvUL
